turn.text: May I just ask this question?
They didn't offer theoretical evidence.
But the Ninth Circuit relied on kind of folksy evidence, that, in fact, the service was less expensive, provided by the competitors, and that sort of things, at pages 10 and 11 in their opinion.
Does that evidence... is that evidence at least raise an issue of fact?

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: Well, they presented a couple of anecdotes in declarations--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: --about incidences in which they've been able to offer service.
But that doesn't begin to rebut the implausibility of the case, in which--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Oh, but if those were typical examples, and if the competitors' prices were roughly half of yours, isn't that some... at least a scintilla of evidence that maybe there was some market power in the service market?

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: --Although it may be a scintilla of evidence, it's not the significant, probative evidence that's required under--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So the question goes as to how much weight to give to that evidence, not whether there's any there at all.

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: --They didn't present any evidence, not even a scintilla, of a fundamental change in the workings of the marketplace that would separate the equipment market from the parts and service market... non that showed how that would work.
Their only theory was a lock-in theory.
That was the only theory they presented to Judge Schwarzer.

And as this Court held in Jefferson Parish, the proper time to assess market power in that instance is at the time of purchase, since that's when... that's when the competing offers are being considered by the purchasers.
And co--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You... you and your colleague on the other side have quite a different notion about what percentage of the parts that Kodak makes and what percentage does it buy.

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You say 75 percent; he says 10 percent.

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: I... on page 293, of the joint appendix, Kodak presents evidence that it has over 10,000 parts in copiers, and over 20,000 parts in micrographics.
It does not say what percentage, at that point.
And I'm unable at this point to find that reference.
However, I submit it makes no difference, what percentage, whether it's 75 or 10.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know your time is up, but--

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: Excuse me.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --Was there a charge that Kodak had an arrangement or an agreement with the... its parts suppliers not to sell to ISO's?

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: There was... there was some inadmissible hearsay evidence of a--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that part of the charge?

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: --Part of the charge of a vertical... only arrangement between Kodak and its suppliers.
And in any event, they have no market power.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know, but I ask you whether... is there a charge that you had an arrangement with your parts suppliers not to sell to ISO's?

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: Yes, that for proprietary information for Kodak parts, it would not be provided.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, let's assume that... let's assume that they could prove that you had this arrangement with your parts' suppliers not to sell to ISO's.
You would be in sort of a lot of trouble, wouldn't you?

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: No, Your Honor, for two reasons.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, why not?

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: One is that it's a vertical arrangement only.
Second--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Vertical?

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: --Yes, they are not horizontal competitors.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I agree with that--

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: Second--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --I agree with that.
But you are... have an agreement with somebody else to exclude somebody from the service market.

turn.speaker: donn_p_pickett
turn.label: Mr. Donn P. Pickett
turn.text: --Yes, much like in the Sharp Electronics case with the retailers.
And in any event, there'd be no market power.
